stem: A 52-year-old client is being transfused with 1 unit of packed red blood cells. Ten minutes into the infusion, the client reports severe lower back pain. Based on the documentation in the Transfusion Record & Adverse Event Monitoring tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Acute reaction during blood transfusion.
Background: Receiving blood for symptomatic anemia. Type AB positive.
Assessment: Client is restless, diaphoretic, and reporting 'tearing' pain in the lumbar region.
Recommendation: Immediate cessation of product.

tabs.title: Adverse Event Protocol
tabs.content: Stop blood. Disconnect tubing. Maintain IV access with new tubing and 0.9% NS. Notify MD and Blood Bank. Send remaining blood and blood/urine samples to the lab.

actionOptions.text: Disconnect the blood tubing and initiate 0.9% NS with new tubing
Send a freshly collected urine specimen to the laboratory
Slow the rate of infusion to 50 mL/hr and continue monitoring

parameterOptions.text: Urine output and color (Assess for hemoglobinuria)
Frequent vital signs (Checking for worsening Hypotension/Tachycardia)
Presence of a maculopapular rash on the trunk
Lung sounds for new onset of crackles

rationale.correct: Acute Hemolytic Reaction (c2) is a life-threatening incompatibility event (e.g., ABO mismatch). Lower back (flank) pain is the hallmark early sign caused by hemoglobin clogging the renal tubules. The nurse must immediately disconnect the blood and maintain the vein with a CLEAN line of Normal Saline (a1) to support BP. Collecting urine (a2) to look for red blood cells/hemoglobin is essential for diagnosis. Vital cycles (p2) and urine monitoring (p1) are critical.
clinicalPearls: Low back pain = Acute Hemolytic. Chills/Temp rise without pain = Febrile Non-hemolytic.
Never flush the line that still contains blood; you would be pushing the 'poison' into the patient.
The blood unit and all tubing MUST be sent back to the blood bank for testing.

questionTrap.trap: Slowing the blood instead of stopping it.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: There is no 'safe' speed for an incompatible blood unit. If a reaction is suspected, the infusion must stop permanently and immediately.

mnemonic.title: Hemolytic Hallmarks
mnemonic.expansion: F-Flank Pain. L-Low BP. U-Urine Red. S-Shaking/Diaphoresis. H-Heart Racing.
